name: SovereignSky Geopolitical Blocs
description: Regional and supranational data governance frameworks affecting digital sovereignty

itemListElement.name: European Union
itemListElement.description: The EU's comprehensive data framework expanded in 2026 to include the AI Act and Data Act, creating a 'Digital Single Market' with binding rules across all 27 member states.
itemListElement.abstract: Supranational bloc with the world's most integrated digital laws.
itemListElement.summary: In 2026, the EU shifted focus from mere privacy (GDPR) to ethical AI deployment and mandatory interoperability for cloud services. It is the primary regulator for global digital standards.
itemListElement.articleBody: The 'Brussels Effect' reached its peak in 2026 with the AI Act becoming fully enforceable in August. This law mandates transparency for general-purpose AI and prohibits high-risk biometric surveillance, influencing how data is processed globally.

adequacyDecisions.notes: Data Privacy Framework (DPF) certified organizations only

itemListElement.name: European Economic Area
itemListElement.description: The EEA extends the EU single market rules, including GDPR and the 2026 AI Act, to Norway, Iceland, and Liechtenstein.
itemListElement.abstract: Extends EU data sovereignty and single market standards to non-EU members.
itemListElement.summary: The EEA ensures that data flows between the EU and members like Norway are treated as internal transfers, provided the members adopt relevant EU acts into their domestic law.
itemListElement.articleBody: By early 2026, all EEA members have initiated the adoption of the EU AI Act. This maintains a 'frictionless' data zone for the entire European single market, allowing companies in Norway to operate under the same rules as those in Germany or France.

itemListElement.name: ASEAN Digital Economy
itemListElement.description: The landmark 2026 Digital Economy Framework Agreement (DEFA) harmonizes digital trade and data flows for over 700 million people across SE Asia.
itemListElement.abstract: A massive 2026 regional pact unifying Southeast Asia's digital markets.
itemListElement.summary: Signed in early 2026, DEFA targets a $2 trillion digital economy by 2030. It sets the first binding regional rules for cross-border data flows and e-payment interoperability.
itemListElement.articleBody: ASEAN's approach in 2026 balances 'consensual sovereignty' with trade. DEFA allows countries like Indonesia to keep specific localization rules for financial data while standardizing rules for e-commerce and AI ethics across the bloc.

itemListElement.name: GCC Trust Zone
itemListElement.description: Led by Saudi Arabia and the UAE, the GCC has unified its data privacy landscape, with Oman's PDPL becoming fully enforceable in February 2026.
itemListElement.abstract: High-trust digital region with strong emphasis on national data sovereignty.
itemListElement.summary: By 2026, the GCC has harmonized its privacy laws to facilitate regional digital trade. However, strict 'Strategic Data' residency requirements remain for government and energy sectors.
itemListElement.articleBody: The 2026 GCC landscape is defined by 'Digital Sovereignty' initiatives. While standard business data is transferable under new regional treaties, sensitive health and biometric data must remain localized in state-approved data centers.

itemListElement.name: Five Eyes
itemListElement.description: A signals intelligence alliance between the US, UK, Canada, Australia, and New Zealand that enables high-level government data sharing.
itemListElement.abstract: Collaborative intelligence bloc with significant privacy implications.
itemListElement.summary: While not a trade bloc, the Five Eyes 2026 status indicates a region where government surveillance and mutual legal assistance can override commercial data privacy.
itemListElement.articleBody: The alliance uses instruments like the US CLOUD Act to access data across borders. In 2026, this continues to create friction with EU adequacy decisions, as 'mass surveillance' remains a core concern for European regulators.

itemListElement.name: AU Digital Single Market
itemListElement.description: The African Union's 2026 roadmap focuses on the 'Continental Data Governance Framework' to ensure African data generates value within Africa.
itemListElement.abstract: Continental initiative targeting 'Data Sovereignty' for African nations.
itemListElement.summary: By early 2026, the AfCFTA Digital Trade Protocol has begun harmonizing cross-border rules, aiming to prevent data fragmentation across the continent's 54 nations.
itemListElement.articleBody: The 2026 focus of the AU is 'Data Colonialism' prevention. The bloc encourages regional data centers and discourages the storage of strategic African population data on foreign soil without reciprocal agreements.
